page.enlisting:
• One of the (under-utilized) success stories of satellite meteorology • Many “snapshots” (hourly) results from geostationary platforms, time-integrated • Simple atmospheric physical model with measured surface albedo used for • Several methods using GOES/Meteosat/GMS data by independent investigators • Daily So usually with < 10% error versus pyranometers • 20 km resolution So Product: North and South America, Australia, Europe • One of the (under-utilized) success stories of satellite meteorology
• One of the (under-utilized) success stories of satellite meteorology

page.enlisting:
• Employ disaggregation using ALEXI (“DisALEXI”) with MODIS thermal data as twice-daily input. • MODIS 250 m visible to sharpen thermal data to >1 km resolution. • Develop regional-scale (e.g., over continental U.S.) disaggregation procedures that relies on MODIS imagery when available. • Develop field-scale available water data sets at MODIS resolution for agriculture and NWP applications. • Use MODIS land-surface products (e.g., NDVI, LAI). • Employ disaggregation using ALEXI (“DisALEXI”) with MODIS thermal data as twice-daily input.

page.enlisting:
• Assume that ALEXI’s total system evapotranspiration is an integrated average of available water within the 0-200 cm soil column. Unfortunately, we know very little about the distribution of available water within that 0-200 cm soil column. • Using the available water profile from NAM/EDAS initialization fields as a first guess of the soil profile, and adjust this profile to fit the integrated average of available water from ALEXI. • Assume that ALEXI’s total system evapotranspiration is an integrated average of available water within the 0-200 cm soil column. Unfortunately, we know very little about the distribution of available water within that 0-200 cm soil column.

page.title:
Current mesoscale numerical models use sophisticated land-surface models to handle the coupling between the surface and the atmosphere.
Current mesoscale numerical models use
sophisticated land-surface models to handle
the coupling between the surface and the
atmosphere.
page.normal_text:
The NOAH-LSM uses a 4-layer soil moisture model to handle the exchange of soil water between the surface, sub-surface and atmosphere.
The NOAH-LSM uses a 4-layer soil moisture
model to handle the exchange of soil water
between the surface, sub-surface and
atmosphere.

Under high vegetative cover, ALEXI loses some sensitivity to handle the surface layer (0-10 cm), and under low vegetative cover, ALEXI loses some sensitivity to the sub-surface layers (10- 200 cm).
Under high vegetative cover, ALEXI loses some
sensitivity to handle the surface layer (0-10 cm),
and under low vegetative cover, ALEXI loses
some sensitivity to the sub-surface layers (10-
200 cm).

We assume that a fraction of evapotranspiration is directly (1:1) related to a fraction of available water, which in turn can be used to calculate a volumetric soil moisture, given values of field capacity and permanent wilting point for the soil type.
We assume that a fraction of evapotranspiration
is directly (1:1) related to a fraction of available
water, which in turn can be used to calculate a
volumetric soil moisture, given values of field
capacity and permanent wilting point for the soil
type.
